Award.AwardTitle: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3: A Self-evolving independent ATP battery for Pseudocells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy is essential for life. ATP is a biological energy molecule used by every known living organism. It is produced inside cells. This project will fabricate and evaluate the novel concept of an "ATP battery" that will continuously produce ATP in a controlled and independent manner. Electronic batteries can power a wide range of electronic devices. The ATP battery would energize a wide variety of synthetic cell functions. The ATP battery would have energy generating cells that convert chemicals fed to them into ATP continuously. The ATP generated could then flow downstream to synthetic cells, powering the production of vaccines, therapeutic drugs or other valuable products. This project also has a detailed education and outreach plan. It focuses on expanding the research experiences and horizons for high school and undergraduate students.

ATP is an ideal energy choice for a synthetic cell. However, efficient production of ATP is currently limited to biological mechanisms. The creation of a controllable means to connect ATP generation to bioprocesses and supply it in a stand-alone manner, i.e. an ATP battery, would support the development of synthetic cells. Therefore, the primary goal of this project is to develop a device producing sufficient ATP in a continuous and controllable manner to drive external synthetic cells. An additional goal is to develop the battery in such a way that it can be evolved to meet the changing requirements of different synthetic cells. The proposed approach is inspired by electric batteries and cellular mitochondria. It builds on the research team's expertise and previous work on DNA hydrogels and synthetic biology. Utilizing cloned ATP synthase genes and combining 3D printing and microfluidics, the research team will build a stand-alone ATP battery that can convert a proton gradient to ATP continuously. The produced ATP will also be used to power the evolution of the battery cells themselves. The self-evolvable nature will make the proposed ATP batteries versatile, enabling applications beyond synthetic cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Adenosine triphosphate, or ATP, is a universal biological energy used in every living cells and by every known organism. However, ATP production is entirely confined within live cells. Outside of living cells, it is extremely difficult to control and harvest ATP.

 

The intellectual merit of the grant outcome is the novel concept of an “ATP battery” that will continuously produce ATP molecules in a controlled and cell-independent manner. Just as electronic batteries can power a wide range of electronic devices, it is envisioned that such a stand-alone ATP battery would similarly energize a wide variety of artificial cells functions ranging from protein expression to locomotion. Towards that end, we have isolated (cloned) all the needed, ATP-related genes including all of the subunites. We have also successfully produced those proteins/enzymes. We developed methods that measured the activities of ATP to make sure that they were functional. We were also successful in integrating the cell-free ATP prodcution with our DNA hydrogels, building up the chasis for assembly of a stand alone ATP battery. We utilized 3D printing and microfluidics to build a cell that were compartmentalized, separating enzymes from pH gradient. We have also managed to encapsulate ATP genes into liposomes in order to integrate into the cell while still keeping the enzymatic activities. Finally, due to the arriving of Covid-19 pandemic, we shifted this research from wet-labs to dry-simulation, explroing diffusion parameters and enzymatic kinetics.

 

Our broader of impacts of this grant focus on expanding the research experiences and horizon for undergraduate students and high school students, especially those minority students and female engineering students who have been unrepresented in the STEM areas. More specfiically, during the grant period, at least two of the undergraduate engineering researchers (both minorities and one is a female student) have been trained extensively; both successfully secured university undergraduate research grants. One will present her research result in a national, virtual conference. In addition, a female high school student interned during the summer. Afterwords, she had been successfully admitted to a prestigous university majoring in biological engineering.
